articles.headline: ‘Red Flag’ Gun Control Bills Pick Up Momentum With G.O.P. in Congress
articles.snippet: Republicans, seeking a response to this weekend’s massacres, are coalescing around such bills to help law enforcement take guns from those who pose an imminent danger.
articles.abstract: Republicans, seeking a response to this weekend’s massacres, are coalescing around such bills to help law enforcement take guns from those who pose an imminent danger.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans, under intense pressure to respond to this weekend’s massacres, are coalescing around legislation to help law enforcement take guns from those who pose an imminent danger — a measure that, if signed into law, would be the most significant gun control legislation enacted in 20 years.

articles.headline: The U.S. Labeled China a Currency Manipulator. Here’s What It Means
articles.snippet: The move is mainly symbolic but will escalate tensions with Beijing.
articles.abstract: The move is mainly symbolic but will escalate tensions with Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration labeled China a currency manipulator on Monday, after China allowed the value of its currency to fall.

articles.headline: Trump Wants a Weaker Dollar. Getting One Isn’t So Easy.
articles.snippet: President Trump has made no secret of his frustration that the United States dollar has strengthened against other currencies.
articles.abstract: President Trump has made no secret of his frustration that the United States dollar has strengthened against other currencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trade war between Washington and Beijing took an unexpected turn this week as China let its currency drop sharply and the United States responded by officially designating the country a currency manipulator.

articles.headline: ‘It Feels Like Being Hunted’: Latinos Across U.S. in Fear After El Paso Massacre
articles.snippet: The shooting attack in El Paso has left many Latinos deeply shaken, raising questions about their place in American society.
articles.abstract: The shooting attack in El Paso has left many Latinos deeply shaken, raising questions about their place in American society.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — After 22 people were shot to death at a Walmart in El Paso over the weekend, a Florida retiree found herself imagining how her grandchildren could be killed. A daughter of Ecuadorean immigrants cried alone in her car. A Texas lawyer bought a gun to defend his family.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero, Caitlin Dickerson, Miriam Jordan and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: How the El Paso Shooting Exposes the Rifts in Texas Politics
articles.snippet: In areas like Sugar Land, Tex., a burgeoning multiethnic population and suburbanites repelled by President Trump are giving Democrats more hope.
articles.abstract: In areas like Sugar Land, Tex., a burgeoning multiethnic population and suburbanites repelled by President Trump are giving Democrats more hope.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUGAR LAND, Tex. — Nearly 700 miles from the El Paso Walmart where the suspect in the killing of 22 people on Saturday denounced a “Hispanic invasion,” Rish Oberoi, a candidate for state representative, gestured toward a bustling dining room in a popular Vietnamese restaurant and marveled at the diversity of this Houston suburb.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Uber Wants to Sell You Train Tickets. And Be Your Bus Service, Too.
articles.snippet: The ride-hailing company, craving growth, is looking to public transit for riders and revenue. Cities aren’t sure whether to welcome it.
articles.abstract: The ride-hailing company, craving growth, is looking to public transit for riders and revenue. Cities aren’t sure whether to welcome it.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — When Julia Ellis arrives at a train station in a Denver suburb to go to work, she opens her Uber app. Next to the ride-hailing options, she taps a train icon marked “Transit.”

articles.headline: 3 Countries Cut Rates as World Braces for More Trade War Turbulence
articles.snippet: Central banks in India, Thailand and New Zealand cut interest rates in what one analyst called “defensive action” amid fears of worsening U.S.-China tensions.
articles.abstract: Central banks in India, Thailand and New Zealand cut interest rates in what one analyst called “defensive action” amid fears of worsening U.S.-China tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Central banks in India, Thailand and New Zealand moved to shore up their economies on Wednesday amid fears that global growth will become the biggest casualty in the spiraling trade war between the United States and China.
